data.title: Hundreds attend service for Middletown man killed in WWII
data.meta_description: The U.S. Army Forces Lt. was shot down over German-occupied France in 1942.
data.text:
MIDDLETOWN, Ohio (WXIX) - Hundreds of people came out to a Middletown cemetery to honor a World War II soldier whose remains were recently identified.

In a sea of red, white, and blue, around 200 people attended the service for Middletown native U.S. Army Air Forces 1st Lt. Dan W. Corson at Woodside Cemetery on Wednesday.

The remains of Corson, who was 27 when he died, were accounted for on Sept. 22, 2023, according to the Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency (DPAA).

Corson was assigned to the 401st Bombardment Squadron, 91st Bombardment Group (Heavy), Eighth Air Force in December 1942, the DPAA explained.

The 27-year-old from Middletown was co-piloting a B-17F “Flying Fortress,” nicknamed Danellen, on Dec. 20, 1942, when the DPAA says the aircraft was hit by anti-aircraft fire following a bombing raid on German aircraft factory at Romilly-sur-Seine, France.

Nine airmen were in the Danellen, but only one managed to parachute out before the aircraft crashed near the village of Bernières-sur-Seine, France, according to the DPAA.

A year after the crash, on Dec. 20, 1943, the DPAA says the War Department issued a finding of death for 1st Lt. Corson.

In 1946, the American Graves Registration Command (AGRC) was given the task of recovering missing American personnel in the European Theater, the DPAA explains.

Four sets of remains were unable to be identified following the end of WWII, and they were interred at the Normandy American Cemetery.

A family member of one of the Danellen crewmembers contacted the Department of Defense in 2011 after they visited the crash site in France. There, the DPAA says the family member talked with a witness who had artifacts belonging to the Danellen.

After seeing the evidence, the DPAA Investigation team went to Bernières-sur-Seine themselves.

Investigators talked with the same witness, learning the crash site was now destroyed.

Eight years later, in March 2019, the unidentified remains were exhumed from Normandy American Cemetery.

Scientists were finally able to identify Corson’s remains, the DPAA said.

Corson’s name is recorded on the memorialized on the Wall of the Missing at Cambridge American Cemetery, an American Battle Monuments Commission site in Cambridge, England, along with others still missing from WWII. A rosette will be placed next to his name to indicate he has been accounted for.

More than 73,000 American soldiers remain unaccounted for from WWII, according to the Soldiers Walk.

Five service members associated with Corson are among the unaccounted-for, DPAA data shows.

The unaccounted-for include:

Staff Sergeant Jackson M. Barbour

First Lieutenant Bruce H. Brown

Technical Sergeant Edwin D. Byrdic

First Lieutenant Reeves S. Carper

First Lieutenant Mark B. Connor
